Welcome to December!  It’s beginning to look a lot like WINTER in the North Lobby of ARIA Resort!

While the North Star is certainly dazzling in the main lobby, it was important that we enchanted all of our guests, regardless of where they enter from. This winter wonderland of smock flocked trees, falling lights, and sparkling cones was installed in the North Lobby just off of Harmon Avenue, above Jewel Nightclub. 

The design welcomes you beautifully into the casino and the patisserie, and it tells the same story of winter nights and starry skies. 

It’s a stunning space for all of your holiday photos and IG moments…

And it definitely showcases the swagger of ARIA’s spaces.

This is #howwevegas

Designer @andreaeppolito

Details, details, details.

Every inch from the mirror topped tables to the stacked chargers and the offset menus were meticulously hand selected to create an environment that was luxe, couture, and romantic.

The warm peach and pink undertones feel right on this chilly winter day as we all look forward to spring and the new year.

Long and lovely, and also romantic, these beautiful mirror top tables allowed us to play with size and scale. The tall, towering floral centerpieces allowed guests to see one another, and we filled in the base with clusters of smaller arrangements to keep the look full and luxurious. 

when guests sit down, there should be some thing interesting for them to engage with. For this wedding, each guest placesetting was topped with an individual bouquet of flowers. And Ivory menu embossed with gold lettering was tucked in between the charger plates, detailing the feast to come.

And while my bride was thinking pink, we added peach accents to give the florals depth and interest.

Which element from this design do you love most?

Forever tossing petals and posing in the middle of the aisle!

There is little I love like an aisle filled with fluffy rose petals. The minute I have a chance to gather them up and toss them around, I take it!  I miss the days when guests tossed petals at the newlyweds…it always make for such a perfect picture. 

Until that trend comes back to the ballroom, I’ll be doing it myself. 

PS - one of the most fun moments post wedding ceremony is pulling the petals off of my heels!  Anyone else feel the same?!?

There’s just something magical about The Bellagio. 

I opened the Bellagio in 1998 when I was just 21 years old, and the space still give me the chills in the very best of ways. 

Couples looking for old-world elegance and romance will forever fall in love with the Grand Patio and the gorgeous wrought iron gate that couples can get married in front of. 

For this bride, we created a lush display of rose petals and aisle markers that appeared to crawl up the gate. The soft pink and ivory petals were a soft contrast to the black chairs and the scrolled gate. 

Up top, we set big, beautiful trees that both added to the fullness of the ceremony location and also his the reception design, allowing us to fully reveal the space later in the evening.

Making my pink and black dreams come true!  The Grand Patio at Bellagio is an iconic space with views of the pools and magnolia trees. with its Terrazzo floors and themed ceilings, it does feel decidedly old world and European. These high gloss, black lacquer tables were built specifically to add a restrained sense of modern contrast to the balcony. We wanted to keep the flowers, soft and pretty, and constrained, the color, palette to shades of pink, champagne, and ivory. To tie it all together, we softly draped, a pale pink fabric from the ceiling, which also created a sense of intimacy.

But what really brought this space to life was the lighting! The delicate build out of this location means that you can’t really read anything too heavy unless you run the risk of damaging the façade. we worked with engineering to create a line of chandeliers, and let them with projection lighting.

Do you like contrasting, modern touches with old world elegance? Drop a comment below.

Where exactly should a sweetheart table be placed in a reception? 

I love setting the table in the middle, directly across from the stage. This allows the couple to see the performances and the toasts, as well as the dance floor, and gives all of the guests a central place so that they can see the newlyweds. 

Be sure to design a stunning stage, as this is what they will be looking at all night long. 

What do you think of this design?  I love the detail of the drape, the chandeliers, and the way the flowers wrap the space and highlight the performers.

Creating an Indoor/Outdoor experience in a ballroom.

Luxury is personal and on purpose.

Many couples come to me for an over the top expression of their love, and that often is displayed through large floral installations and centerpieces. 

But sometimes, luxury is about restraint. Luxury is about quality, individual pieces coming together to tell a cohesive story.  These tables were designed to create a feeling of residential elegance. All of the couple’s homes have beautiful dining rooms with large wooden tables, topped with orchids and terrariums. For this design, we wanted to invoke the feeling of coming together with family and friends, a sense that you were entering a scared and intimate space where good food, good friends, and good times were guaranteed. 

If you look beyond the tables, you see chandeliers glistening in the distance, another nod to their glamorous style and way of life. 

Tell me, which do you prefer… Over-the-top expensive florals or the restraint of low and luxe designs?

✨ What do you feel when you walk into a room? ✨

When guests walk into a room, I want them to be overwhelmed. I want them to see everything at once, and then, as their eyes settle, they can take in the details. And these details were so good...Every element from the shades of white to the gold rimmed chairs, the black accent napkins, the marble runway and the hanging crystals were hand selected to add to the overall ambiance and experience. 

That is why I love a full-room photo. It’s a shot I always ask for, because it perfectly captures the size and scope of a space.  And this one happens to be magnificent.

I. Am. Obsessed.

Welcome to my ceremony dream come true!

When Jessica and Rob invited me into their lives, I had no idea the journey we would go on together. They were ideal clients in every sense of the word. They allowed me the freedom to design, play, and explore. They opened up to me completely, and allowed me to fully see who they are as people, which allowed me to design and experience that fully reflected their personalities.

Jessie asked for something dark and romantic, with luxe touches that celebrated her love of contrast. She didn’t want to be overly floral forward, but she didn’t want something too austere. 

Getting married in the mountains of Lake Tahoe in the winter almost guarantees snowfall. To celebrate the season and the location while still keeping guests completely comfortable, we built a stunning atrium that allowed guests to take on the mountains, trees, and snow. 

I love a good tree moment, but I wanted some thing different from what I had done before. I kept seeing enormous, but barren trees, with flex of gold.  Given that my bride loves jewelry and has a tremendous collection, we created a ceiling filled with rough, hand cut gems that fell from the sky and mixed them with the tiniest lights so that they would sparkle with warmth as she walked up the aisle. The floor was completed with a high gloss vinyl that reflected the ceiling. To add just a touch of romance we included large floral mounts between the clusters of black leather chevron backed chairs. 

We built this in a blizzard, with 40+ mph winds & over 4 feet of snow. It was the most intricate installations of my life under the more difficult weather conditions. I could not be prouder of the teams or the final result. 

Swipe right to see the production and my initial reaction (at 3 am!) when I walked the lighting grid.

I don't create for pictures. I create for people. The spaces we build and the environments that we design are stunning displays are art, but they come to life when people are inside of them!

This atrium was over 1,0000 square feet, filled with over 125,000 strands of twinkle lights. The trees stood 12 feet hight and were hand carved in Styrofoam, covered in a hard shell, and painted antique gold. 

Mounds of florals dotted the aisle way, bringing life to this space. It was ephemeral in the best sense...Taking a team of over 40 men 6 days to build. 

And then, just like that....It was gone. But for one, perfect night it was ours. And it was perfect.

Design is often times answering questions and finding solutions….

Like how to turn a smaller space into a grand affair. 

This mountainside ballroom was filled with wood, busy patterns, and heavy texture. To create the feeling of expansion and space, I followed the lines!  Quiet literally, I designed long, sleek tables to mimic the linear pattern of the ceiling. They draw the eye forward, making it feel as if the space just goes on forever. 

By covering the walls and floor in a high gloss black finish, the tables appear to float in space, seeming to go on forever. 

And can we talk about the way the white flowers pop against the black tables?!?

Chalet Chic Welcome Reception.

We kicked off this wedding weekend with a chic and sexy chalet-inspired bash.

This design is all about tonality, texture, and details. 

We started with a natural color palette based in shades of beige and brown. I wanted to play off of wood and bark and natural stones with soft, feminine touches such as velvet, fur, and roses. 

You know I love a circular bar, and we topped this one with natural, woven basket lighting.  We brought in wooden vases filled with ivory, brown, and antique toned roses. Special appearance made by a 12 foot tall, hand-carved bear. 

This party was absolutely everything!  More images to come…

Always make an entrance….

People forget that events start outside of the ballroom.  the guest experience begins as you turn the corner and approach the space. 

For this chalet-chic inspired welcome party, we carpeted and draped the hallway to create a cohesive feel between the ballroom and the pre function space. 

This also allowed us to introduce key elements, such as the color palette, natural elements such as stone and wood, and motifs such as the antlers. 

Incorporating the pre-function space also allows us to expand the ballroom, adding square footage where there was none, finding a unique location for a bar, and connecting the patio to the ballroom in a seamless fashion.

I wish we were decorating MORE hallways for our couples!  Do you love this trend?!?

Tables that go on for days….

Design is about solving problems. In this case, we were working with a very small ballroom that felt narrow at the entrance. To create a sense of depth we tricked the eye with long, lean lines of tables, chairs, and florals that mirrored the paneling of the ceiling. Our high gloss, vinyl flooring creating a water-like effect, creating the idea of depth and shimmer. 

In so many ways these tables seem to go on forever, leading straight into the darkness of our blacked out walls. 

Forever a favorite in terms of the layout, and can we have a moment for those candelabras?!?!

Details, details. 

This week I had the opportunity to speak at my alma mater @unlvhospitality and one of the students asked how they can differentiate themselves in a saturated market. I told them it’s about the details. 

Not just the details of design, although they are certainly vital to the success of an event, but it is the details in how you manage your business and your life. It’s about how you present to the world. It’s the pretty AND the process. 

This tablescape is dark and dramatic, but still sweet and romantic. We created a modern, high gloss foundation with black acrylic tables, brought them to life with candlelight and gold charges, and topped them off with lush pink roses. Then we placed with shapes. A starburst charger, round menus, and slick squared off table numbers. 

You see a thoughtful, meaningful representation of my couple:  modern, opulent, dramatic and romantic. What you DON’T see are the three samples of menus we cut to ensure the size was perfect, the three different chairs we sat at the select the right one, or the 2 different finishes for the table top. 

Pretty follows process. Details are everything.  And hard work trumps all.

Why play small when more is more?!?

Reposting this beauty with a reminder to go all out this weekend.

Trees, lush florals, and massive displays.  I’m a more is more kinda girl, and these things makes me feel alive.

My clients wanted abundance, color, and depth of expression.  They wanted to interpret their life through design, to introduce themselves to family and friends, and to set the stage for the rest of their lives together.

Yes I am now known as the planner who does the trees. Purple, green, metallic, and white. I am okay with that for so many reasons.

My husband’s favorite childhood book was The Giving Tree. I had never read it, but we got it for my son. I hated the book, initially. The boy was so selfish and I wanted my son to be the antithesis of him.

But I loved the tree. I loved how the tree was willing to give anything and everything for the boy. Shade, limbs to climbs, apples to eat, and wood. There was nothing the tree would not sacrifice.

What a beautiful message to bring to a wedding. To say that these two people are willing to give all they are to the other, and to their union.

2019 was the year of the tree.  2020 was the year that never was. 
Design meeting after design meeting this week, and I can’t wait to show you what we are building out in 2021.  This will be the year of...

Never underestimate the power of a kiss. 

Or of ceremony design. So many couples focus on the wedding reception, which initially makes sense. It’s where you spend the most time, and so logically it’s where you spend the most money and effort. 

This is the dream…

But I love starting with the ceremony. This is why we are here. This is what matters. And this is the first impression that your guests have when they enter the space. 

The ceremony sets the tone for the rest of the event. It is where your family and friends come together, where you come together, and the kids at the end of the ceremony signals that the party had begun.

Details, details…

It’s often the little things that make a big impact on your wedding. Scroll through these images, and take a note of all the little details that we brought together to create this tablescape. Then, tell me what’s missing…
.
.
.
.
The answer is NAPKINS! This table was so beautiful, with so many special touches, such as the individual bouquets tucked into crystal vases, the thick, triple, ply, menus, all of the gold accents… Trying to force a napkin fold onto the tablescape would have been a mistake. Instead, we “lapped” the napkins, meaning that a server placed them on the lap of each guest as dinner service was about to begin. This only took moments to do, and it added an elevated experience that allowed our guests to feel catered to.

How do you make your wedding stand out from the rest?  What makes your wedding special?

One of the easiest ways to create a compelling design is to play with your table arrangements. A lot of people immediately think of round tables with the occasional long banquet table, added in for interest. There are so many other options to consider! A serpentine table is one that whines through the room. You can modify the seating and the length by simply connecting the pieces at the edge. You end up with a really compelling interesting, set up that sneaks through the room. Typically, these tables are not as wide as other options. This requires you to get creative with your centerpieces. Opt for something tall that adds height and interest without taking up too much surface area.

These tables featured smaller clusters of florals at the base, and the drama came from the shape, and the tall candelabras that followed the line of the design.

Do you like the unique tablescape or do you prefer a traditional round? Leave your comments below.

I. Am. Obsessed.

Welcome to my ceremony dream come true!

When Jessica and Rob invited me into their lives, I had no idea the journey we would go on together. They were ideal clients in every sense of the word. They allowed me the freedom to design, play, and explore. They opened up to me completely, and allowed me to fully see who they are as people, which allowed me to design and experience that fully reflected their personalities.

Jessie asked for something dark and romantic, with luxe touches that celebrated her love of contrast. She didn’t want to be overly floral forward, but she didn’t want something too austere. 

Getting married in the mountains of Lake Tahoe in the winter almost guarantees snowfall. To celebrate the season and the location while still keeping guests completely comfortable, we built a stunning atrium that allowed guests to take on the mountains, trees, and snow. 

I love a good tree moment, but I wanted some thing different from what I had done before. I kept seeing enormous, but barren trees, with flex of gold.  Given that my bride loves jewelry and has a tremendous collection, we created a ceiling filled with rough, hand cut gems that fell from the sky and mixed them with the tiniest lights so that they would sparkle with warmth as she walked up the aisle. The floor was completed with a high gloss vinyl that reflected the ceiling. To add just a touch of romance we included large floral mounts between the clusters of black leather chevron backed chairs. 

We built this in a blizzard, with 40+ mph winds & over 4 feet of snow. It was the most intricate installations of my life under the more difficult weather conditions. I could not be prouder of the teams or the final result. 

Swipe right to see the production and my initial reaction (at 3 am!) when I walked the lighting grid.

Mounds of florals dotted the aisle way, bringing life to this space. It was ephemeral in the best sense...Taking a team of over 40 men 6 days to build. 

And then, just like that....It was gone. But for one, perfect night it was ours. And it was perfect.

Let’s take a closer look at this layered table design. 

For our round tables we wanted height. I asked that the centerpieces echo the shape and of the tables and that we keep them round and full. I didn’t want to obstruct the view, which is why we used crystal vases. I didn’t want the tables to feel too too heavy, so we added a lower layer of petite arrangements and candles to the base of the design for balance. 

My last and final ask was that the flowers continued to spill out onto the table so that the base extended for an incredibly full look. We accomplished this by adding individual bouquets to each place setting. By doing this, we not only balanced out to the top of the centerpieces, but we also balanced the ceiling, which was so heavily filled with orchids and roses. 

Do you like this full design or do you prefer a more minimalistic approach?

Tall, towering centerpieces.

Let’s talk about it. This wedding was designed with a central aisle that connected one side of the ballroom to the other. Our tables and chairs were set on each side of the walkway, and I wanted to create height. With a mix of both long and round tables, we buried the shape of the centerpieces, but not the flowers that they were created with.

Each table featured over the top topiaries comprised of white roses, hydrangeas, and orchids. They were packed tightly to avoid any hints of greenery and to keep the pristine white color palette. 

At the base of the tables we added clusters of white roses in various sizes and shapes. 

Because I wanted all of our guests to be able to see the central aisle (and each other) we used crystal and glass vases that friends and family could see through and around. 

And, of course, we added candlelight. 

These tables are a MasterClass in height done right and still are one of my most beloved designs.

So many details came together to create this contemporary wedding design celebrating all things Italian. 

My bride wanted something that gave a nod to the traditional European setting without feeling too thematic. I introduced modern elements such as the high gloss black table and the black chairs to are a chic touch to the stone space. Pale pink florals helped bridge the gap between old world elegance and the romance of today. 

I wanted the wedding cake to really lean into the Italian vibe. I set it on a column up against a stone fountain, and wrapped both pieces in the same flowers to create a cohesive visual that was decidedly romantic and lush. 

The place settings and tables were a stark contrast and much more modern. The black lacquered tables offered us a mirror-like shine and reflection, while the round, black menus with rose gold-foil print were a bit more grounded and tactile. 

My couple loved the final design and the story we told by creating a story between the old and the new.

The Wedding Ceremony Gate. 

Gates are a symbol I often incorporate into my designs.  They are a physical representation of moving from one space to another.  When we place a gate, it is a visual cue that we are taking our guests on a journey, and that there will be a moment of transformation and change. 

These black wrought iron gates are a staple at The Bellagio.  I dressed them in roses and greenery shaped to look like Angel wings. Just a small nod to the heavenly space we were in without making it feel too literal.

Details, details. 

When asked how you can differentiate themselves in a saturated market, I say that it’s all about the details. 

Not just the details of design, although they are certainly vital to the success of an event, but it is the details in how you manage your business and your life. It’s about how you present to the world. It’s the pretty AND the process. 

This tablescape is dark and dramatic, but still sweet and romantic. We created a modern, high gloss foundation with black acrylic tables, brought them to life with candlelight and gold charges, and topped them off with lush pink roses. Then we placed with shapes. A starburst charger, round menus, and slick squared off table numbers. 

You see a thoughtful, meaningful representation of my couple:  modern, opulent, dramatic and romantic. What you DON’T see are the three samples of menus we cut to ensure the size was perfect, the three different chairs we sat at the select the right one, or the 2 different finishes for the table top. 

Pretty follows process. Details are everything.  And hard work trumps all.

“This is my second Andrea Eppolito wedding…”

Wow! While walking through Vanessa and Roberts‘s wedding reception (swipe) a couple stopped me to tell me that this was the second time they were at a wedding I produced. They said that as soon as the doors open, they instinctively knew that it was one of mine. And as they saw me walking through the space the wife said, “There’s the Boss Lady…”

Why does this bring me so much joy?  I created two completed different designs for two completely different couples. Distinctly different layouts. Totally different color schemes.  And yet, when these guests walked into the room they knew instinctively that it was mine. Why…and how?

Because in the end, it’s never about the stuff. It’s about how the stuff makes you feel. 

Those are my feelings. I create them. And that’s why ever little detail of design matters…Because of how they make you feel. 

Wedding D&CJ

social_posts.post_text:
Quiet Luxury Weddings:  This wedding ceremony was an exercise in restraint. My focus was on tonality and texture, shapes and light. 

My bride wanted something very soft and neutral, but warm. Bright white would have felt too aggressive to her, too stark. Instead, I started with a slightly warmer, ivory colored carpet, and then I surrounded the room in a deeper champagne drape. The chairs, which had a beautiful, curved back that sloped down the sides, was more of a nude color.

To create the aisle, I did use a truer shade of white in eggshell. Bright enough to be noticed, but nothing that was going to stand out and look out of place. The boxes were covered with an interesting mix of florals. Our creamy roses were full and lush, opened wide, with a touch of hydrangea worked in. At the bottoms and peeking out around the edges were small blooms of freesia. 

The subtlety of the color-way allowed the candles to really dance in the space and light the couple’s walk down the aisle. 

For someone who believes that more is more, designing with restraint really forces me lean into other skills and techniques, and I’m so grateful that we did!  In the end, my bride walked down the aisle and had everything she wanted. 

Do you like the look of a clean, restrained ceremony or do you prefer something over the top and opulent?  Let me know in the comments below.

We all know that I love a good tree moment!  I worked with @dolcefiore__ to create massive trees with golden trucks and leaves dripping with crystals and wrapped in roses. Mirror topped tables encircled these centerpieces and served as our Honor Tables for the bride and groom’s immediate family members. 

We placed clusters of roses around the interior of the tables to keep them looking full and lush, and added up lights to help the crystals sparkle. 

The rest of the table was intentionally light and airy, with textured glass chargers trimmed and gold that matched our gold rimmed glassware. 

Romantic, deeply feminine and ethereal, these tables were one of my favorite elements of the reception. 

Swipe 👉🏻 to watch these tables be assembled onsite.

Where exactly should a sweetheart table be placed in a reception? 

I love setting the table in the middle, directly across from the stage. This allows the couple to see the performances and the toasts, as well as the dance floor, and gives all of the guests a central place so that they can see the newlyweds. 

Be sure to design a stunning stage, as this is what they will be looking at all night long. 

What do you think of this design?  I love the detail of the drape, the chandeliers, and the way the flowers wrap the space and highlight the performers.

This towering 16 foot tall tree makes me look positively tiny. While I’m only 5’4 barefoot, I stand at almost 5’9 on wedding days with my shoes on.  That’s the power of size and scale. 

By adding massive installations to your ballroom we can change the way that the space is perceived. 
These pieces made our wedding reception feel full and lush. Sitting beneath the golden leaves felt intimate and cozy, and the guests at the surrounding tables marveled at the size and fullness of our VIP honor tables which is where we sat the parents and family of our bride and groom. 

I love a good tree moment, and these felt extra special in our space.

COMING SOON: Design 

I’ll be in studio today filming a course on design (launching at Wedding MBA) to help educate and inspire wedding professionals to lean into their visions, bending the world to their will and creating never before, never again moments, like this one. 

Bird’s Eye View for days….

After months of obsessing over every element - from the carpet’s shade of white to the sheen on the champagne traps - it’s so satisfying to step back and see it all come together.

This room was really a study in neutrality, specifically in shades of white. A year before, I had done a wedding in cool white tones. My couple found it very inspiring, but I wanted to do something uniquely different for them. In designing the space, I really wanted to lean  into the warmth of white. Playing with different shapes and textures really allowed us to appreciate the tonality and the different shades that we had brought into the space.

Do you prefer warm, white, cool, white, or bright white? Let me know in the comments below.

What does it mean to design?  Is it just about the pretty, or does design require process?  Who is design for? And does it even matter?!?

My WEDDING DESIGN  MASTERCLASS will be available for purchase starting tomorrow at Wedding MBA.  It has been created to help other move from imitation to inspiration and - ultimately - creation. 

I don't just create for pictures. I create for people. The spaces we build and the environments that we design are stunning displays are art, but they come to life when people are inside of them!

This atrium was over 1,0000 square feet, filled with over 125,000 strands of twinkle lights. The trees stood 12 feet hight and were hand carved in Styrofoam, covered in a hard shell, and painted antique gold. 

Mounds of florals dotted the aisle way, bringing life to this space. It was ephemeral in the best sense...Taking a team of over 40 men 6 days to build. 

And then, just like that....It was gone. But for one, perfect night it was ours. And it was perfect.

Engagement Photos to Bridal Portraits…It’s about telling a better story. 

Every decision you make is an opportunity to say something and share a little bit about how you see the world. 

Darrian is all romance and glamour. She is rooted firmly in her femininity, while still being strong and confident. 

When we were designing her engagement photos, I wanted to give a nod to her love of flowers and production. Giving a hint of what was to come in terms of colors and lushness, we were able to create a consistent look and feel while having the freedom to switch in terms of texture and tone. 

I just love how beautiful she looks, and how completely comfortable she seems in these photos. We bent the universe to her will, we created something whimsical and romantic, and for one…no…TWO days the world was a perfect place.

Black and white weddings are all the rage, but producing such a start design takes an incredible amount of commitment and production. When done right (and to the max) there are few installations that look more luxurious than black and white.

Many couples love, the look of a black and white wedding, but want to soften it a bit. They are looking to add a little bit more life and expand their options. For this, nothing works better than layering and fresh greenery. By infusing hanging greenery in the ceiling and green leaves green leaves in the centerpieces in the centerpieces, we were able to soften the look of this wedding reception while keeping all of the glam.

Do you love the look of black, white, and green…or do you prefer to focus only on black and white?

So many details came together to create this contemporary wedding design celebrating all things Italian. 

My bride wanted something that gave a nod to the traditional European setting without feeling too thematic. I introduced modern elements such as the high gloss black table and the black chairs to are a chic touch to the stone space. Pale pink florals helped bridge the gap between old world elegance and the romance of today. 

I wanted the wedding cake to really lean into the Italian vibe. I set it on a column up against a stone fountain, and wrapped both pieces in the same flowers to create a cohesive visual that was decidedly romantic and lush. 

The place settings and tables were a stark contrast and much more modern. The black lacquered tables offered us a mirror-like shine and reflection, while the round, black menus with rose gold-foil print were a bit more grounded and tactile. 

My couple loved the final design and the story we told by creating a story between the old and the new.
